I need to make sure I answer right, like I really saw them, and then give some excuse. 

‘But he would’ve told you right away that the workers couldn’t have been there two days before. So, you must’ve been there on the murder day at eight. That’s how he would’ve caught you on that detail.’

‘Yeah, that’s what he was banking on. He wanted me to rush and give the most obvious answer, so I’d forget the workers weren’t there two days ago.’

‘But how could you forget that?’

‘It’s easy! Smart people get tripped up by dumb stuff. The more clever someone is, the less they think they'll fall for a simple trap. Porfiry isn’t as clueless as you think….’

‘So, he’s a trickster then!’

Raskolnikov couldn’t help but laugh. But then he realized how weird it was to be so open about it, especially since he’d been acting all gloomy before, clearly with a purpose. 

‘Am I starting to enjoy this?’ he wondered. But just like that, a sudden, uneasy thought hit him. His anxiety grew as they reached the entrance to Bakaleyev’s.

‘You go in alone!’ Raskolnikov said suddenly. ‘I’ll be back.’

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov reflects on the cunning nature of deception and the ease with which intelligent individuals can be ensnared by simple details.
